llm_processed_output.source_summary: This chapter, titled "The Battle of Zallaqa Between Mythos to Logos," directly discusses the Battle of Zallaqa (1086). It examines written accounts of the battle, focusing on the accounts within the framework of a mythos-logos binary. The chapter analyzes two poems composed shortly after the battle and a historical account from a 15th-century encyclopedia. The author explores how the works of a poet and historian address the battle, noting changes in the relation between Arabic poetry and prose, and highlighting the ways in which the texts share common themes and cross discursive boundaries while narrating the same event. The chapter mentions key figures like Alfonse VI of Castille and Galicia (r. 1077–1109) and al-Mu‘tamid Ibn ‘Abbad, Prince of the emirate of Seville (r. 1061–1091).
extracted_key_facts: The Battle of Zallaqa took place in 1086.
The battle occurred in the southwest region of al-Andalus (modern Spain and near the Portuguese border).
The battle was between Alfonse VI, King of Castille and Galicia (r. 1077–1109), and al-Mu‘tamid Ibn ‘Abbad, Prince of the emirate of Seville (r. 1061–1091).
The source analyzes two poems composed in the immediate aftermath of the battle.
The source examines a historical account taken from a historical encyclopedia written in the fifteenth century.
The poems were composed by ‘Abd al-Jabbar Ibn Hamdis (d. 1133).
The historical account was penned by Muhammad Ibn ‘Abd al-Mu’min al-Himyari.
The chapter aims to show the gradual change in the relation between Arabic poetry and prose.
The texts share common tropes and themes, and cross each other’s discursive boundaries all the while telling the same story in oddly similar ways.

llm_processed_output.source_summary: This thesis examines the historiography of the Taifa Kings era (1013-1086), focusing on how the Andalusi ulama (religious scholars) are understood by contemporary historians. It argues that historians often view the ulama as a homogeneous group opposed to the Taifa kings. The author challenges this by dividing the ulama into "mosque ulama" and "palace ulama," and argues that the sources are often narrated from the perspective of the "anti-taifa mosque ulama." The thesis provides historical context, including the Arab-Berber conquest of Iberia, the Umayyad Caliphate, and the rise of the Taifa system (1013-1069). It also discusses external pressures, like Alfonso VI of Leon-Castile and the Almoravids, including the Battle of al-Zallaqa. The source analyzes primary and secondary sources, highlighting the dominance of the anti-taifa perspective in chronicles and other historical works, and outlines the historical scope of the study covering the years 1013 to 1094 with a special focus on 1085-1094.
extracted_key_facts: The thesis subject is the historiography of the Taifa Kings era (1013-1086).
The study addresses how the 'ulama' (Muslim religious and legal scholars) of this period are understood by contemporary historians.
Contemporary historians often view the Andalusi ulama as a homogeneous group that shared a common point of view regarding Taifa politics.
The thesis challenges the understanding of the Andalusi ulama.
The purpose of the thesis is to identify various groups within the ulama and then determine their attitude to the Taifa system.
The thesis divides the Andalusi ulama into "mosque ulama" and "palace ulama."
Most historical sources for the taifa kings era are narrated from the point of view of a subset of the mosque ulama.
This small group was opposed to the taifa kings and supported their overthrow.
The period covered by the study is 1013-1094, with a special emphasis on 1085-1094.
The taifa kings era began with the capture and sack of Cordoba by Berber forces in 1013.
The taifa kings era ended with the arrival of the North African Almoravids (al-Murabitun) in al-Andalus in 1086.
The years 1086-1094 were a time of political transition in Muslim Spain.
The historical context includes the Arab-Berber conquest of Iberia and the Umayyad Caliphate of Cordoba.
The taifa system lasted from 1013-1069 (competitive politics).
External pressures include Alfonso VI of Leon-Castile and Ibn Tashufin, the Almoravid Emir.
The Battle of al-Zallaqa occurred.
Primary sources discussed include historical chronicles, literary anthologies, biographical dictionaries, and memoirs.
Ibn al-Kardabus (d. 1174), Ibn 'Idhari (d. ca. 1312), and Ibn al-Khatib (d. 1374) are important chroniclers.
Al-Dhakhira by Ibn Bassam is a literary anthology.
Biographical dictionaries such as Al-Sila fi tarikh a'immat al-Andalus by Ibn Bashkawal and Kitab al-takmila li-kitab al-sila by Ibn al-Abbar are also relevant.
The memoir of 'Abd Allah ibn Buluggin (The Tibyan) is discussed.
Secondary sources include works by Reinhart Dozy, E. Levi-Provencal, Hussain Mones, Peter C. Scales, David Wasserstein, Maria J. Viguera Molins, and Dominique Urvoy.

llm_processed_output.source_summary: This thesis examines the interaction of religion and politics in Reconquista Spain from the mid-9th to the end of the 14th century, focusing on the treatment of religious minorities.  It challenges the "golden age" and "convivencia" narratives, arguing that political decisions were primarily based on local interests and expediency rather than a global "clash of cultures." The thesis provides a detailed historical overview of the Reconquista, including the disintegration of the Umayyad Caliphate into taifa kingdoms, the role of Christian martyrs in Cordoba, and the military and political strategies of Christian rulers like Alfonso VI and Alfonso VII.  It analyzes the experiences of Jewish and Muslim communities under Muslim and Christian rule, highlighting periods of tolerance and persecution. The thesis also examines the repoblacion (repopulation) period, Mudejar revolts, and the increasingly intolerant atmosphere leading to the expulsion of Jews in 1492 and Muslims in 1610.  While acknowledging the impact of religion, the thesis emphasizes the complex interplay of political, economic, and social factors driving events.
extracted_key_facts: The thesis examines the interaction of religion and politics in medieval Iberia (mid-9th to late 14th centuries), focusing on the treatment of religious minorities.
The Reconquista is presented as driven by local interests and concerns, not a global "clash of cultures."
The Umayyad Caliphate's disintegration into taifa kingdoms in 1031 created a power vacuum exploited by Christian kingdoms.
The martyrdoms of approximately 48 Christians in Cordoba in the mid-9th century are discussed as a factor contributing to tensions between Christians and Muslims.
Alfonso VI of Leon and Castile's ambition to unite Iberia under his rule is highlighted, showing his strategic alliances with Muslim kingdoms.
The Battle of Sagrajas in 1086, where Alfonso VI was defeated by the Almoravids, is mentioned as a significant turning point.
The Almoravids' and Almohads' invasions from North Africa are analyzed for their impact on religious tolerance and the treatment of minorities.
The experiences of the Jewish community under Muslim rule (Al-Andalus) are examined, challenging the "golden age" myth and acknowledging periods of both tolerance and persecution.
The massacre in Granada in 1066, resulting in the death of Vizier Joseph ibn Naghrela and many Jews, is discussed.
The Almohads' forced conversions of Jews in the 12th century are mentioned.
The role of Jews in translating Arabic, Greek, and Hebrew texts is highlighted.
The Christian experience is analyzed, contrasting the motives of Christian leaders with the crusader rhetoric.
The capture of Toledo by Alfonso VI in 1085 is presented as a significant event.
The capture of Cordoba by Ferdinand III in 1236 is seen as a turning point, marking the end of an era.
The repoblacion (repopulation) period after the Reconquista is discussed, focusing on the assimilation of remaining Muslim and Jewish populations and the resulting tensions.
The Mudejar revolts are analyzed, highlighting the complex causes including Castilian policies, the role of Nasrid Granada, and religious pronouncements.
The legal treatment of Mudejars is contrasted with their actual experiences, revealing official tolerance alongside widespread discrimination.
The role of the Papacy in encouraging conversions and its influence on the Reconquista is discussed.
The experiences of conversos (converts from Islam or Judaism) are examined, including the challenges they faced from both former and new communities.
The pogroms of 1391 against Jewish communities in Castile and Aragon are described as a major turning point, illustrating the increasing intolerance.
The role of Vicente Ferrer in converting Jews and the resulting consequences are noted.
The Siete Partidas legal code is referenced as evidence of the complex legal framework concerning religious minorities.
The expulsions of Jews in 1492 and Muslims in 1610 are presented as outcomes of the evolving religious and political climate.
